'''''The Orgog''''' is the title of an unfinished and unpublished<ref name=rg>{{CG|RG}}, p. 499</ref> children's tale written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] "around [[1924]]" about "a strange creature traveling through a fantastic landscape".<ref name=firstmention>{{HM|AH}}, p. 5</ref>

== Background ==
When the Tolkien family had moved in [[1924]] to 2 Darnley Road in Leeds,<ref name=AI>{{HM|AI}}, "Art for Children", p. 77</ref> [[John Tolkien]] recalls that ''The Orgog'' was one of the tales read by his father to him, when he could not fall asleep.<ref name=chronology>{{CG|C}}, p. 125 (entry "17 March 1924")</ref><ref name=rg/> While most of these tales were not written down,<ref name=chronology/> ''The Orgog'' survives as an unfinished, typewritten manuscript.<ref name=AI/> Not much is known of the story itself, except that it is a "strange, convoluted tale of an odd creature travelling through a fantastic landscape"<ref name=AI/> and includes "blue mountains and an orange sun"<ref name=AI/>.<ref name=firstmention/>

It has been suggested by [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] that Tolkien's watercolour ''A Shop on the Edge of the Hills of Fairy Land'' (painted in 1924) is likely related to the tale,<ref group="note">The painting appears as figure no. 71 in {{HM|AI}}.</ref> as the word "Gogs" appears on the depicted shop building, though there is no mention of such a shop in the tale. However, like ''The Orgog'', it also has "blue mountains and an orange sun". The painting is dedicated to John. In September [[1936]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] accidentally tore it up, though Tolkien repaired it.<ref name=AI/>

On [[22 June]] [[2025]], [[Jason Fisher]] mentioned on his blog that he had been told that ''The Orgog'' "really isn’t in a state suitable for publication" in a private correspondence.<ref name=lingwe>{{webcite|author=[[Jason Fisher]]|articleurl=https://lingwe.blogspot.com/2025/06/the-ulsterior-motive-and-other.html?m=1|articlename=“The Ulsterior Motive” and other unpublished writings of Tolkien|dated=22 June 2025|website=Lingwe|accessed=23 June 2025}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
The meaning of "orgog", and if the word has any connection to one of Tolkien's invented [[:Category:Languages|languages]], is unknown. It was speculated by Jason Fisher on his blog that the word may{{blockquote|relate to “[[Ogres|ogre]]”, perhaps connected with [[Hilary Tolkien]]’s (and Ronald’s) childhood tales of black and white ogres. Or there is the character of Orgoglio from Edmund Spenser’s ''The Faerie Queene''. That work was more to Lewis’s taste than Tolkien’s, but you never know. In that work, Orgoglio is a monster who attacks Redcross Knight in Book One, Canto VII. The name, interestingly enough, is Italian for “pride”, from Vulgar Latin *''orgollium'', in turn from Proto-West Germanic *''urgollju'' “pride, arrogance”.<ref name=lingwe/>}}

== Inspiration ==
Although it might be a mere coincidence, the name ''Orgog'' is reminiscent of [[Wikipedia:Orgoglio|Orgoglio]], the name of a giant appearing in Book I of [[Wikipedia:Edmund Spenser|Edmund Spenser's]] ''[[Wikipedia:The Faerie Queene|The Faerie Queene]]''.<ref group="note">For a mention of Orgoglio in the context of Tolkien's writings, cf. Jonathan Evans, "Pride" in [[Michael D.C. Drout]] (ed.), ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien Encyclopedia: Scholarship and Critical Assessment]]'', p. 543.</ref>
